Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story:
Every year, my stepmother insists that everyone in the family attends the holiday dinner, no exceptions. She says it’s important to uphold our family traditions, especially since I’m still learning to fit in. Tonight, as I’m setting the table, my phone buzzes. It’s Jamie, an acquaintance from my art class. She’s in town for just one night and asks if I can recommend a good restaurant nearby. She sounds lost and a little desperate, and I know she doesn’t know anyone else here.

I glance at my stepmother, who’s watching me, expecting me to be present and engaged, not distracted by my phone. I feel the weight of her expectations—be a good step-child, show respect, participate fully. But Jamie’s message tugs at me too. I want to help her, to be the kind of person who’s there when someone reaches out. My mind races, torn between the warmth of the family gathering and the pull of being helpful to someone who needs me. I stare at my phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which one I’m supposed to belong to right now.
